learning_objectives.label: Differentiate radial nerve lesions by level and expected motor/sensory deficits
Differentiate median nerve lesions (proximal, pronator syndrome, AIN) and hallmark signs
Differentiate ulnar nerve lesions (canal vs elbow) and expected patterns
Recognize superior brachial plexus (C5–C6) lesion patterns and implicated peripheral nerves
Recognize inferior brachial plexus (C8–T1) lesion patterns and implicated peripheral nerves
Identify normal upper‑limb structures and common variants on XR/CT/MRI/US
Recognize common radiographic views and match each to structures best evaluated
Integrate upper‑limb clinical cases (e.g., vasculitic mononeuritis multiplex) with nerve/muscle exam findings
Describe femoral nerve territory and function (anterior thigh, saphenous distribution)
Describe sciatic nerve branches and typical deficits by lesion
Differentiate common peroneal (fibular) nerve lesion patterns
Recognize tibial nerve deficits and posterior compartment function
Identify anterior leg compartment actions and innervation (deep fibular)
Identify posterior leg compartment actions and innervation (tibial)
Recognize knee joint features and movements relevant to function
Trace external iliac to femoral to popliteal transitions and major branches
Apply venous valve pathophysiology to varicose veins/DVT scenarios
